document.text: Washington.The program which the American Farm Bureau will sub mit to the National Agricultural Con ference will call for early enactment by Congress of laws clearly defining the rights of the farmers to market their products co-operatively. In making this announcement the bureau said their economic and legis lative proposals would be based upon the plan adopted at the recent annual convention in Atlanta, Ga. At the same time it was said information which the Department of Agriculture is collect ing on farm tenantry and other prob lems will be made available to the delegates. James R. Howard, president O. E. Bradfute, vice-president, and members of the executive committee, it was an nounced, would represent the Federa tion at the conference. Six women were Included in an ad ditional list of 3 names of delegate made public by Secretary Wallace. They are Mrs. Nellie F. Blakeman, Oronoque, Conn., chairman of the home economics committee of the Na tional Grange Mrs. Charles W. Sewell, Otterbein, Ind., leader in Farm Bureau womans work Mrs- John Black, Roslyn, Md., leader in grange work Mrs. J. W. Jones, Olney, Md., leader in farm womens activities Mrs. Frank B. Black, Myersdale, Pa., president of the Society of Farm Women of Penn sylvania, and Mrs. W. C. Martin, Dal las, Texas, State chairman of the Fed eration of Rural Life Clubs. Among other delegates in the list are George Livingston, Washington, former chief of the Bureau of Mar kets, and S. S. Pennock, Philadelphia, president of the Society of American Florists and Ornamental Horticultural- ists.

The pastor of the church will deliver the sermon and music will be rendered by his choir. Impressive Pre-Thanksgiv ing services were held at the Galilee Baptist Church last Sunday morning at the 11 a.m. service. The pastor delivered the message. Music was rendered by the Senior Choir. Despite the rain an apprecia tive crowd came out. The Mount Shiloh Baptist Church will conduct its annual religious service at the Pine View Nursing Home this Sunday evening at 2 p.m. Music will be rendered by the Senior and Junior Choirs of the church. The pastor will deliver the message. Friends are invited to attend. The Mens Club of the Mount Shiloh Baptist Church will sponsor a Three Way Sermon on the first Sunday in December at 3 p.m. The Reverends W. R. Jones, J. W. Paige and C. L. Elliott will be the guest speaker. Music will be rendered by the Senior Choir of the church. The public is cordially inyited to attend. All members ahd friends are cordially invited to attend the regular preaching service at the Promise Land Baptist Church this Sunday morning at 11 a.m.

document.text: OurColored Debaters. The colored people of Oakville met in the public school house near that place to discuss the subject, Our Present Needs. The speakers were Rev. E. Austin, Jr., W. J. Jones, aud J. R. Johuson, Rev. Austin being the first speaker. He was followed by W. J. Jones, af ter which a recess was taken and a nice dinner was served on the lawn. At 230 oclock J. R. Johnsons address renewed the exercises, S. J. Hunter next took the stand and sought to impress upon his hearers the necessity of the colored standing together. After a speech by S. Cheatham benediction was pronounced by Rev. E. Austin, Jr., and then all went- home rejoicing.

document.text: this Sunday morning at 10 a.m The churches involved are asked to have all candidates ready at 10 a.m. Immediately following the baptizing service the regular preaching service will follow. The right hand of fellowship will be given at the close of the morning message and the Lords Supper will be adm inistered. The general public is cordially invited to attend. Seating capacity of the Appo m attox Elem entary Schbol was taxed to its capacity last Sunday evening when the Appomattox Trumpteers cele brated its nineteenth annivers ary. Every community in the county was represented and many guests from outside the local community. The Rever ends W.R. Jones and J. W. Paige assisted in the program. The Rev. R. Q. Lawing and the Galilee Baptist Church Senior Choir took a part in the installation of the Rev. Dr. G. N. Marshall as pastor of the Mount Pleasant Baptist Church of Rt. 2, Gladys, Va. last Sunday evening at 6 p.m. The youth program sponsor ed by the Youth Club of the Mount Shiloh Baptist Church last Sunday evening at 3 p.m. was enjoyed by all. Miss M argaret Calloway Burns served as mistress of cere mony. Music was rendered by the Mount Shiloh Junior Choir under Mrs. C.S. Turner for the devotional period. Scripture was read by Miss Gail Tanner and prayer was offered by Miss Bridgette Watts and a very cordial welcome was extended by Miss Marzatte Hodnett Mrs. T. W. Hamlett responded to the welcome. The special guest, The Pinn Family Singers of Madison Heights was introduced and presented by the youth leader, Mrs. Rowena Robinson. The offering was very good. The final remarks

document.text: The general public is cordial- i ly invited to attend the annual union baptizing services held at the P r o m i s e Land B a p t i s t Church this f o u r t h S unday ! morning beginning at 10 a.m. 1 Candidates from Galilee, Mount Shiloh, Promise Land and Morning Star will be baptized ! At 11 a.m. regular preaching services will be conducted and the Holy Communion will be served. A large crowd attended the fifteenth anniversary of theAp- j pomattox Trumpteers last Sun day evening at 730 in the audi- j torium of the Appomattox Inter mediate School. The Reverends W. R. Jones and J. W. Paige j served as m asters of ceremony. The following groups appeared on the program The Johnson j Family of Lynchburg The Holi-  ness Gospel Singers of Pamp- j lin The Gospel Echoes of Dan-  ville, and the Waynesboro Sing- ! ing Aires of Waynesboro. The j general offering was lifted by j Deacons James C h r i s t i a n of Amherst, Deacon W. Hancock  of Appomattox and Deacon Cal- I vin Elliott of Spout Spring. Ordination services will be i held at the Mount Airy Baptist j Church this Sunday at 3 p.m. for the following young men as deacons of the Mount Airy Bap tist Church M essers Joseph Berry, Edward McCoy and Al W. J o h n s o n . M e m b e r s and friends of local churches are cordially invited to attend. The Rev. H. W. Pryor is taking this opportunity to invite ministers and deacons to attend. Impressive services w e r e held at the Galille B a p t i s t Church last Sunday morning at the regular preaching hour.Spe cial music was rendered by the combined choirs of the church. Several visitors attended the service. Mrs. Letha Moss was the month leader. She reported the sum of 50.25 during the offering period. Mr. Tom Davis is receiving special treatment in the Lynch burg General Hospital. Mrs. Lillie Stevens spent the week end in Roanoke, Va., as the g u e s t of relatives an d friends. The public is reminded of the trip to Baltimore on the third Sunday in October. The bus will leave at 6 a.m. in the morning. Rev. Lawing will deliver the homecoming message at the Peaceful Zion Baptist Church in Lynchburg on the first Sunday in October at 3 p.m. Music will be rendered by the Galilee Junior Choir. The Rev. J. W. Paige is con ducting the annual revival at the Mount Pieler Baptist Church this week. Friends are invited to attend.

document.text: The East and West Bound Sunday School Union will convene with the Chestnut Grove Sunday School this Sunday at 1000 a.m All schools are asked to be presented. The day sessu begin with the Sunday School lesson. The first business will begin at 1100 a.m. The annual sermon will be delivered by the pastor of the church. The president will bring recomendations for the new year. Refreshments will be served by the home school at the close of tije business session. The general public is cordially invited to attend. The general public is cordially invited to atend the anniversary celebration of the Mount Shiloh Church Usher boards, on the first Sunday evening at 3 p.m. The Rev, Wyatt T. Venable and his church choir will be the special guest. Mrs. Lucinda Lewis, president will serve as mistress of ceremony. A musical program by Mr. James Braxton of the Rose Chapel Baptist Church will be presented at the Promise Land Baptist Church on the second Sunday in November at 3 P.M . On the first Sunday evening at 6 P.M . the Rev. R. Q. La wing and the Galilee Senior choir will be the special guest at the Mount Pleasant Baptist Church at H ixburg. Members and friends are reqeusted to attend. The general public is invited to attend a special service sponsored by the Pastors Aid Society of the Zion Baptist Church this Suhday at 11 a.m. The Rev. James Franklin of West Virginia will be the guest speaker. Impressive service was held at the Promise Land Baptist Church Sunday morning. The Rev. K . W. Davis was the guest speaker. Beautiful music was rendered by the senior choir. He was assisted in the service by the Rev. A . B. Jones. A very large crowd attended the regular preaching service at the Mount Pleasant Baptist Church last Sunday morning. The Rev. Mr. Ghee of the High Rock Baptist Church was the guest speaker. He was assisted in the service by the Rev. H. 0 . Flood who served as master of ceremony and the Rev. R. Q. Lawing. All officers of the Assembly are asked to attend the next Council meeting on Wednesday Nov. 3rd at 730 P.M . at the Galilee Church Fellowship Hall. We are very happy to report the Reverends W. R. document.text: Shown abc-ve is a copy of the 5-cent Appomattox Commemora tive postage stamp, fifth and final in the Civil War Centennial series. The stamp will be issued April 9 with ceremonies here at Appomattox and will include an official visit from the assistant postmaster general, William M. McMillan. Lonard Fellman, 44- year-old commercial artist of Edina, Minnesota, designed the stamp, an unsolicited stamp de sign which met with approval from Postmaster General John A. Gronouski. It is a rarity for 1 unsolicited designs to be accept ed for postage stamps. Fellmans designs shows a soldier and stacked rifles sil-  houetted against a blue a n d gray background. A phrase from Lincolns second inaugural ad- I dress  with malice toward none . .  catches the mood I of the event at Appomattox that was to lead to the end of hos tilities. At the top of the stamp ap- I pears Civil War Centennial in  black, and beneath this Is Ap- I pomattox in white. Both are in  modified barnum, as are the dates  1865-1965, in b l a c k , w h i c h appear vertical left. United States Postage, In j white sans serif capitals is at the j base of the stamp and the de- I nomination 5 cents is lower i right. Of the five stamps in the Civil  War centennial series, this is the j sole vertical design. It was mod- i cled at the Bureau of Engrav ing and Printing by Robert J. j Jones. Arthur W. Dinlaman en-  graved the vignette and letter  ing and numerals are by George j A. Payne. One hundred fifteen I million will be printed on the Giori press in black and blue.

document.text: l ii i c k i i iK h a i i i. At a largely attended mass-meet ing B. F. Nuckola was nmde chair man and _ P. Grigg, secretary. Fhe object of the meeting was the adoption of the resolutions printed below, bidding fuiewdl to tbe old County Court system, and the strong ndorsement of Judve Moss, as a Tair and impartial judge, who has -irerided over the court for the past twelve .rars. Col. Kobt. T. Hub bard. Hon. E. W. Hubbard, A. P. Grigg and others spoke feelingly to the resolution and Judge A. 8. Hall, while not opposing the resolution, -aid he was glad the constitution bad abolished the Conntv Court -ysteni. The resolution was adopt ed, and the Messrs. Hubbard and Col. James Lyons were appointed a committee to inform Judge Moss of I - he action of the meeting, and the Judge came forwa-d and in a few well chosen remarks thanked the bar and the meeting for the expres sions of confidence and esteemed the resolutions contained. Whereas our English ancestors rod their decendants in America have for nearly a thousand years had i court of tbe shire, or county court for hearing and determining the minor controversies of the people, a court especially intended for the masses of small means to save them from journeys and heavy expense, nd whereas such local tribunal is t great convenience to them and either it or some substitute will be necessary for letting to bail, ap pointment of guardians and person- 1 representatives, probate of wills tnd etc., therefore Resolved, by this mass-meeting  -f citizens of Buckingham county, held at this December connty court, 1903, that we regret the change in the, constitution abolishing this court. 2nd.  That in severing our rela tions with the incumbent, Judge John R. Moss, we bear cheerful testimony to tbe intelligence, integ rity, ability and dignity with which he has discharged the duties of County Judge, and in his retire ment will carry with him our best i wishes for bis wellfare. 3rd. That these proceedings be certified to the County Court with the request that they be entered on I the minutes of the Court. Jndge Moss will tender his resig nation as Connty Judge of Buck ingham as soon as the present term is adjourned, and will assume his duties in the Legislature the first of the year. Governor Montague! will be requested to appoint Jndge Crute, of Farmville, to hold the I January term. In the Court the only case of any importance was that of J. A. Le- Sneur  Bro., applicants for liquor license at lpha, which was opposed by a large petition to the Judge, ask ing that license be not granted. The Jndge continued the case, and ren dered an opinion, in which he said he had rather the new Court would pais upon the application for . li cense when there is objection. J. A. Trent ws granted  license to sell liquor near Arvonia, there being no opposition to him. Peter Coles, of Albemarle, and Mr. Addie Spencer were hunting at New Store last week. They were! the guests of Mr. L. D. Jones. Mr. J, W. Word has been ap- to the position of store keeper for the National Government at a salary of 2 per day. It iB said Mr. Wiley Hubbard will be married on the 16th to a Miss Sims. Marriage licenses have been is sued during the month as follows Jas. P. Andrews to Emma Lang- horn Gantt, J. E. Pnrvis to Mary E. Miles. Mr. Henry Glencrossi Hebditch to Mies Ora Kyle Spen- oer, at Enon church on December 23rd at noon. The young lady is a daughter of Willis Bocock Spencer, and the groom to be is a son of Mr. J. W. Hebditch. I Justice Garnett held a trial Mon-1 day night, and fined Isiah Moss 5 1 and cost for swearing upon the i.reet, and placed him under a peace bond of 200. Mr. William Spencer, is perhaps, the happiest travelling man who represents a Lynchburg house. He sold for the Quin-Marshall Co., in about eleven months time 100,000 in drygoods and notions. When this fact was reported to Mr. Spen cer, he promptly served notice ou his employers that he had a vaca tion due him. His request was granted and for two weeks be has been the guest of his brother, Mr. Sidney Spencer, down in old Buck- iugham, where he has made many a fleety buck bite the dost before his unerring aim. December 15, 1903.

document.text: Charlottesville.For tbe purpose of putting an end to the series of burg laries from which the .University of Virginia community has suffered, a number-of students have organized,a Vigilance Committee. The follow ing men, most of whom have been ap pointed by Judge John W. Fishbume, of the Circuit Court, as special police for Albemarle county, comprise the committee at present Harry Varner, assistant football coach Pichegru Woolfolk, captain of next falls foot ball eleven M. S. Fitchett, member of last years baseball team Wylie Cooke, ex-captain of the track team T. H. Todd, P. H. Bailey, W. A. Jones, J. S. Graves, John B. Jenkins, E. W. Smith, Jr., George B. Eager, Jr., Sid ney Davis, Nelson Harris, Bernard Meredith, Jesse Ford, J. C. Lamb, W. H. Whitmore and Dr. J. A. WaddelL The objects of the committee are to raise by. subscription from the stu dents, faculty and members of the community a large sum of money to be used in employing expert detectives and in obtaining bloodhounds to use in tracking the criminals to ask the co-operation of the community In de tecting the burglars by reporting any possible clue, and to promulgate rules which will require the procurement of a license badge by such persons as are servants within the University, and to arrest or prosecute those who have no business in the neighborhood.

document.text: At the top of the stamp ap pears Civil War Centennial in black, and beneath this is Ap pomattox in white. Both are in modified barnum, as are the dates  1865-1965, in black, which appear v e r t i c a l left. United States Postage  in white sans serif capitals is at the base of the stamp and the denomination 5c is lower right. Of the five stamps in the Civil War centennial series, this is the sole vertical design. It was mo deled at the Bureau of Engrav ing and Printing by Robert J. Jones. Arthur W. Dintaman en graved the vignette and letter ing and numerals are by George A. Payne. One hundred fifteen million will be printed on the Giori press in black and blue- Collectors desiring first day cancellations may send address ed envelopes, together with re mittance to cover the cost of the stamps to be affixed, to the Postmaster, Appomattox, Virgin ia, 24522. Postage stamps and personal checks will not be ac cepted in payment of the new issue. The envelope to the Post master should be endorsed First Orders for covers must not in clude requests for uncanceled stamps. Requests must be post marked not later than April 9, 1965.

document.text: There will be a grand tourna ment at Appomattox Depot Nov. 17th, 1899. Tilting to commence promptly at 1oclock, p. in. Ball at Hotel Atwood at night. The charge to the Knights will be de livered by Hon. H. D. Flood. The coronation address by Col. R. B. Berkley, of Farmville, Va. This bids fair to be a most enjoyable oc casion. document.text: The annual meeting of tjie l East and West Bound Sunday School Union will convene with the Zion Baptist Church Sunday School at 10 a.m. this fifth Sun day. The pastor, Rev. H. J. Hendericks, will deliver the spe cial sermon. Special music will be rendered by the Home Choir. The youth program will be made up of talent from the different schools. The public is invited to attend. Impressive services were held at the Promise Land Baptist Church last Fourth Sunday at the regular 1130 a.m. service. The pastor delivered an inspir ing message from the subject Why We Should be Thankful. All present enjoyed the mess age. The Senior Choir rendered special music. Several visitors attended the service. The special offering for Hayes Day was lift ed at the close of the morning worship. An appreciative crowd attend ed the Three Way sermon at the Morning Star Baptist Church at Evergreen last Sunay evening at 3 p.m. The Rev. R. Q. Lawing served as m aster of ceremony. The following ministers took a part in the service Reverend J. W. Paige, Winston Jones and C. L. Elliott, The music was rend ered by the New Hope Baptist Church Choir of Campbell. The offering was lifted by Deacons Booker Martin and Mr. Wheaton of the New Hope Baptist Church. Mr. Earnest Abbott gave words of welcome an appreciation. The service was sponsored by the Morning Star Baptist Church Sunday School. Members and friends of the Cornerstone Baptist Su n d a y School Union are asked to meet at the Promise Land Baptist Churchat 10 a.m. in its regular meeting. An appreciation service has been planned for the Rev. R. Q. Lawing, pastor of the Galilee Church for the third Sunday aft ernoon in December at 3 p.m. The special committee is headed by Miss H. B. Stephens. Mem bers and friends of local church es are cordially invited to at tend. The Rev. Emmette Palm er and his Cross Road Baptist Church choir will render special services at the Galilee Baptist Church on the first Sunday eve ning in December at 3 p.m. This program is being rendered by the Galilee Church Choir. This lot contains one half acre, ts beauti fully and conveniently situated for the con duct of most any kind of business, and has on it a splendid, large two story store bouse, agood guano house and a storage house, TERMS OF SALE  One third cash on day of sale, the residue in two equal install ments, to be cvideuoed by two bonds of pur chase, with approved security, payable six and twelve months, respectively, from day of sale, with interest thereon from date. Possession given on May1st. JOEL T. CAWTHOBN, M. L. COVINGTON, J. F. PURDCM, THOS. HARVEY, F. B. JONES, Directors. By W. J. TRENT, Secy.

document.text: of Appomattox county, and Miss Annie L. Plunkett, the lovely and accomplished daughter of the late Willis A. Plunkett, for many years the highly esteemed Sheriff of this county. The church was artistically decor ated, thé altar lined with beautiful flowers and brilliantly illuminated with colored lights. Immediately in frontof the chancel was an arch of flowers, from the centre of which was suspended a floral design in the shape of a horseshoe with the inscription! Good tu c k . It was under this the young couple stood to plight their troth, the Gne to the other. At the appointed time the bridal party entered the church in the fol lowing order  First came the ushers, Mr. Hunter Smith and Mr. Walter Cheatham, down the right and left isles respect ively. Then came the bridesmaids and groomsmen  Miss Elma Shearer with Dr. J. H. Abbitt Miss Susie Jones with Mr. W. J. Trent. . - ,  , -, -. Miss Daisy Lawson, of Bróoknéal, with Mr. Charlie Hunter. Miss Florine H u n t,, of Prince Edward, with Mr. Joseph Button.  Miss Sallie Rica with , Mr. John Overton. MisS Annie Abbitt with Mr. R. W. Stratton. Miss Jessie Cheatham with Mr. Hicks Rice. Miss Vashti Reynolds, of Brook- neal withMr. Hunter Tones. Mr. Robert Harvey immediately preceded the bride and Miss Hattie Plunke the groom. The bride, witlfher sister,Miss Minnie Plunkett, as maid of honor, came down the left isle, and the groom, with his best man, Mr. L. H. Gilliam, came down the right, and met under the arch, where they were declared man and wife in a solemn and impressive man ner by the Rev. Mr. Royall, of the Baptist Church. The arrangement of the bridal party abont the altar, the mellow lights and profuse decorations creat ed a scene of beauty rarely witnessed. The Bride was becomingly attired in a white surah silk, en train, a tulle veil caught up by a diamond brooch. A bouquet of Maréchal Neil roses, tied with white satin ribbon, was carried in her hand. The bridesmaids were air attired in white silk, wifh natural flowers, the gfoomsmen in conventional black. After the ceremony was over ,the bridal pgrty, together with other in vited guests, repaired to the residence of Mrs. D. P. Robertson, mother of the groom, where a reception was tendered them. There was also present the bridal party of Mr. Robert G. Robertson, another son who had been married that morning in Amherst county. After a season of merry-making among the yonng folks, and on the part of the older ones, indulging in reminiscences of similar scenes in which they were the central figures, the assembled party was invited into supper. And such a supper ! A long table, a d o r n e d with flowers, in the centre of which was a large floral pyramid. It was laden with the choicest viands, and beg gars description. . Suffice it to say that it was an old-time Virginia spread,! which the guests did ample justice. It was not until the wee s ma hours that the guests departed, wishing the newly wedded ones, long and happy lives. Besides the two bridal parties there were present, Shearer, Katie Thomas, Annie Col lins, Mary Evans, Mrs. Rufus Bates, Mrs. C. Inge, Mrs. Dan Evans, Mrs. John Hanter, Dr. and Mrs. D. Mott Robertson, Mr. and Mrs. C. T. Plunkett, of Lynchburg, Mr. and Mrs. W. C. Nowlin, Mr. and Mrs. Geo. Hunt, of Prince Edward, Mr. and Mrs. F. W. M cKinnney, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel McK inney, Mr. and Mrs. 3D. R. Abbitt, Mr. A. Plunkett, of Lynchburg, Mr. H. C. Shearer, j Mr. Walton McKinney, and a host of others.

document.text: b y hope generally win out. The question of a business maua ger for the town is still a subject of discussion and earnest consideration. If a business man of the council owned the town of Farmville and had the selection of a man to man age its affairs for him no mistake would be made, but when men as sociate to do work for the people so often the, level business heads leave them. In Washington they play politics, peanut politics, but in Farmville we should sail clear of I such folly. j Hon. W. A. Jones addressed the I voters of harmville and the sur rounding country on the afternoon of the 18th, and though the houi was not wisely chosen he had a large and attentive audience to hear him. His speech here didnt differ from those made elsewhere, but it must be confessed that ho profoundly im pressed many who heard him. A supporter of Senator Martin re marked as he was leaving the court room, Senator Martin will have to come and defend himself or else he wid lose many votes. 1 heard Mr. Jones some years ago when he was fignting Republicans and not Demo- cVat s and have often said since that it was one of the strongest speeches I had heard in a decade, but Some how no man very much moves upon me when he is waging war on mem bers of his own party. It may be necessary, but the washing of dirty linen in front yards isnt a pleasant sight to look upon. It is now said that there was no necessity for cutting down the hade trees on our Main street, and if not then a great wrong has been penetrated upon our people. A tree is mans genuine friend and to have ones friends removed makes ugly gaps. What think you of those news papers that refuse advertisements of the politicians provided the mat ter is clean? Such men I somehow feel mast be rare indeed.

document.text: 8 n  i f be so desired or he might keep them together another week, or even until Christmas, and yet they would never be able to come to any posi tive agreement. . Upon this most positive announce ment Judge Hundley dismissed the twelve faithful men, and they were allowed to go to their respective homes from which they had been absent so long. The jory stood nine for conviction and three for acquittal. Those for acquittal were G. W. Moss, of Shep herdsLeou Pollard, of Shepherdsand B. L. Apperson, of New Canton. Those for conviction were David L. Jones, W. D. Brown, J. H. Cox, H. F. Baughan, J. M. Oslin, W. T. Hndgirs, W. A. Maxey, B. B. Hanes and C. H. Agee. This result vjas a great surprise to many, yet it is safe to say that the majority of the people rather ex pected i t Many had begun to think after Mr. Hubbards great speech this morning, that the result would be a conviction, and early this after noon there were hundreds upon the oonrt green who confidently expect ed a verdiot of guilty. The court opened at 8 oclock this morning. Mr. Flood resumed his argument for the defense, and spoke for an hour with intense force and earnestness. The conclusion of his speech was a masterly piece of eloquence and wisdom. Seldom has snoh oratory been heard in this county before. When this lawyer took his seat the expression upon the faces of his magnificent audience showed what a powerful effect his speech had made. Mr. Edmond W. Hubard made the closing argument for the Common wealth from-9 oclock in the morn ing until past noon. He had the closest attention of the jury and of a vast crowd of people. It would be hardly doing tbe speech justice to say it was a great oue in many respectB it was magnificent. The speaker, who is always a man of eloquence and of force, was in the best of trim, his voice was strong, his intonation clear, and his argu ment was a well-nigh perfect one from all lawyers standpoint. He took the case from its very beginning and brought down every possible point in order and made out of the whole a terrific arraignment of the prisoner at the bar. At times bis denunciation of the crime, and of the criminal, was awful. As a prosecutor, Mr. Hubbard is unsur passed. Many p ominent visitors healing him to day, said they con sidered Mr. Hubbard the finest pros ecutor in the State. From his speech

The class  Education Week will be ob- r evening served at the local Carver Price High School beginning this Sun day evening at 8 p.m. with a developed sppcial address by the Rev. C. L. Brown and his choir frm the Sulphur Spring Baptist Church. The public is cordially invited to attend this service. A special school sendee will be held on Wednesday and Friday at 1 p.m. Mrs. Carol P. Jones, Elementary Supervisor of schools in Buck ingham. Mrs. J. C. Webb is chairman of the special commit tee. An appreciative crowd attend ed the sppecial dedication ser vice at the Springfield Baptist Church last Sunday evening at 3 p.m. The Rev. R.. Q. Lawing and the Senior Choir of the Gali lee Baptist Church were the spe cial guest. Robes for the Spring- field Choir and its minister were formally dedicated. The dedica tion prayer was offered by dea con J. W. King. Mrs. Delores Jones served as mistress of cre- monies and Mrs. Arabell McCoy read the scripture. The welcome address was given by M iss Izet- ta Lewis. All present enjoyed the service. Mr. Anderson Haskins has mov ed into his new home in Appo mattox, Va. Mr. and Mrs. Leon Stovall, of Richmond, spent the week end here as the guest of her mother, Mrs. N. R. Jordan. R. Q. Lawing, Jr. and Miss Walston, of Heathsville, spentì the week end here as the guests of his parents.
